clusters.title: Queenslanders on alert as multiple bushfires burn out of control
clusters.neutral_headline: Bushfires prompt evacuation warnings in Queensland

items.title: Queenslanders on alert as multiple bushfires burn out of control
items.standfirst: Residents in the Southern Downs, Bundaberg and Somerset regions have been warned to prepare to evacuate as several bushfires burn out of control.
items.content: Emergency evacuations are underway as multiple fast-moving bushfires threaten properties across Queensland.Residents in the Southern Downs, Bundaberg and Somerset regions have been warned to prepare to evacuate as several bushfires burn out of control.Up to 300 people have been evacuated from a campground at Lake Wivenhoe in the Somerset Region where a large grassfire has been burning near the Brisbane Valley Highway since about 1.30pm.READ MORE: Police trying to get into mind of accused cop killer as manhunt continuesResidents in Lake Wivenhoe, about 70km west of Brisbane, were warned to prepare to leave at about 4.15pm as conditions worsened.Firefighters are on scene between Brisbane Valley Highway, Logan Inlet Road and Fig Tree Road.The fire is travelling towards Logan Inlet Road and nearby residents are urged to prepare to leave. A watch and act warning was also issued for The Glen in the Southern Downs region about 4.20pm, where a fast-moving fire is burning near between Granite Hills Road, Pikedale Road, and Rockland Road.Firefighters have been working all afternoon to contain the blaze, which has burnt through 700 hectares since 9.30am.Residents have been warned to enact their bushfire survival plans and prepare to leave the area.Further north, a third blaze is burning through sugar cane paddocks in a rural town near Bundaberg.Firefighters have just brought the blaze, which is burning near Des Loeskow Road in Alloway, under control.A "prepare to leave" warning has now been downgraded to "stay informed" but locals are being warned to remain on high alert.In the last 24 hours firefighters say they have been battling more than 89 vegetation fires across the Sunshine State.The bushfires have cast heavy smoke across parts of the state, with authorities advising locals to stay indoors and close windows and doors.Strong winds are also believed to be hampering efforts to contain the fires. At this stage, no properties have been lost, according to the Queensland Fire Department."All structures are being reported as safe, we haven't lost anything just yet, so crews are working really hard to make sure that continues," State fire controller Enes Seferovic said.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

The fires are fast-moving and threatening homes.

clusters.title: Funeral dates set for the police officers killed in Porepunkah ambush
clusters.neutral_headline: Funeral arrangements set for slain police officers
bullet_summary: The funeral arrangements have now been confirmed for the two fallen officers killed in Porepunkah

items.title: Funeral dates set for the police officers killed in Porepunkah ambush
items.standfirst: Private ceremonies will be held for two police officers killed in the line of duty in rural Victoria on Tuesday.
items.content: F uneral dates have been confirmed for two Victoria Police officers killed in the line of duty at Porepunkah on Tuesday.Detective Leading Senior Constable Neal Thompson and Senior Constable Vadim De Waart will be farewelled with full police honours at a private ceremony at the Victoria Police Academy in Glen Waverley.Senior Constable De Waart's funeral will take place on September 5, while Detective Leading Senior Constable Thompson will be farewelled on September 8.READ MORE: Police trying to get into mind of accused cop killer as manhunt continuesThe pair died on a property in Porepunkah, about 300km from Melbourne, when they and a third officer were ambushed while serving a warrant for alleged child sex offences to Dezi Freeman.The third officer was seriously wounded and is recovering in hospital, while the manhunt to locate Freeman, who fled the scene, continues.The tight-knit Alpine community continues to rally around the force in what has been described as some of its darkest days.Players, umpires and officials at local football and netball clubs have committed to wearing blue bands during this week's finals matches, in honour of the two fallen officers.Floral tributes continue to grow at Wangaratta Police Station, as people travel far and wide to pay their respects to the two officers.Earlier today, members of the Veterans' Motorcycle Club travelled f rom NSW to pay tribute at the police station.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

clusters.title: Groom-to-be killed in nasty crash mere months before his wedding
clusters.neutral_headline: Groom-to-be dies in car crash before wedding

items.title: Groom-to-be killed in nasty crash mere months before his wedding
items.standfirst: A man has died in an horrific single-vehicle crash in Adelaide's north weeks before he was due to reunite with his fiancée ahead of their wedding.
items.content: A man has died in an horrific crash in Adelaide's north, mere months before he was due to reunite with his fiancée ahead of their wedding.Jagseer Boparai was driving to work in wet conditions at about 2am when he veered off Cross Keys Road in Salisbury.His vehicle then careered into a tree, a bus shelter and then a Stobie pole.READ MORE: Police trying to get into mind of accused cop killer as manhunt continuesThe 37-year-old was killed on impact."I heard like a thunder at first and then Draco decided to bark because he felt something else was strange," witness Pamela Arakaza said.Boparai was planning to travel back to India with his brother in December, where Jagseer would be reunited with his fiancée, to then get married."I can't imagine how his partner would feel," nearby resident Duhsak Lal said."They're a few days or maybe months away from having the happiest moment of their life and now all that is taken away."READ MORE: Queenslanders on alert as multiple bushfires burn out of controlCross Keys Road was closed into the afternoon as major crash detectives completed their investigations, as onlookers struggled to come to terms with the confronting scene."We can't even open the gates. We can't go to church either and we're just stuck here just looking at this scene every now and then," Lal said.SA Power Networks crews began work on reconnecting nearby homes and businesses after the Stobie pole was bent 90 degrees in the crash.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.content: A 37-year-old man due to get married within weeks has been killed on his way to work in Adelaide.

ai_summary: A man died in a single-vehicle crash.
The crash occurred in Adelaide.
The man was weeks away from his wedding.
He was on his way to work when the crash happened.
He was due to reunite with his fiancée.

clusters.title: Homes raided as manhunt for accused cop killer continues
clusters.neutral_headline: Police search for accused cop killer continues

items.title: Homes raided as manhunt for accused cop killer continues
items.standfirst: Police are probing associates of accused cop killer Dezi Freeman, as interstate resources continue to pile into Victoria's alpine region.
items.content: Police are probing associates of accused cop killer Dezi Freeman, as interstate resources continue to pile into Victoria's alpine region amid difficult weather conditions.Tactical officers today widened their search for the alleged gunman, closing in on a property in the neighbouring town of Myrtleford.A property in Bright was also raided last night, where a 61-year-old man was arrested over drug and weapon offences.READ MORE: Blizzards, powerful winds bring destruction to multiple states He claims to not know Freeman personally, but admits they were in online groups together.With at least 450 police resources now on the ground in the small Victorian town, Victoria Police has been forced to move its forward command post.Previously stationed at Feathertop Winery in Porepunkah, authorities are now using government buildings in nearby Ovens to direct operations as rain, wind and freezing temperatures hit the state. "The new site is a fit-for-purpose facility and will best support Victoria Police's operational activity moving forward," a Victoria Police spokesperson said."We would like to reassure the community that police are not leaving the area."Locals and visitors to the area will still see police activity in and around the Porepunkah and Alpine communities."Police trying to get inside the mind of accused killer P olice are trying to get inside the mind of accused cop killer Dezi Freeman as the manhunt enters its fifth day, a criminologist has said.Criminologist Vincent Hurley said Freeman could remain at large for a number of days, as he has the advantage of hiding in an area he knows well.Hurley said the thing that would weigh on him physically is not being able to rest.READ MORE: Accused cop killer will need to survive brutal forecast as Porepunkah search continues"It's his backyard, the thing that's going against him will be the weather and whether he's got anything out there, like ammunition stashed away, food or extra clothing," Hurley said."The weather conditions will wear him down physically as well as psychologically, he'll be out there there having no rest, he'll always be on edge, thinking that the police are watching him and will find him.""The police got the advantage at this point in time."More than 450 police officers from across the country are involved in the search for Freeman, five days after he allegedly ambushed and killed two Victoria Police officers.His 15-year-old son and wife are in police custody, with Hurley saying police would be speaking to them to try and figure out Freeman's mindset."They would be trying to gather information from those two about the firearm capacity that he might have, his state of mind, what actually triggered this event," Hurley said."They will be trying to work out all those logistical things behind the scenes, and that information will be passed on to the negotiators to get an understanding."He's a sovereign citizen, he's a right-wing extremist...that group of individuals are very much anti-police, so they'll be trying to work out his frame of mind. "It appeared to be a spur-of-the-moment thing." Freeman allegedly fatally shot Detective Leading Senior Constable Neal Thompson and Constable Vadim De Waart on Tuesday morning at a home in Porepunkah.A third officer was allegedly shot and wounded in the leg and is recovering in hospital.Freeman is a self-described "sovereign citizen" who is known to police.Hurley said police appealing to Freeman in a public press conference "gives him an out" if he wants to turn himself in."He will know that there are options available to him; he is not being boxed in, which will play on his mind," he said."He will have to have options in his mind about what lies ahead in the future... my gut feeling is that he won't come out of his own free will because he's allegedly murdered two people, nearly a third.""I don't think it's going to end well."DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.standfirst: Jamie, Ewan and Lachlan Maclean set world record as they arrive in Australia after rowing 14,000km from Peru to CairnsThree Scottish brothers have set a new record for rowing nonstop across the world’s largest ocean, arriving in Australia to the tune of bagpipes and a fresh pizza after 140 days at sea.Jamie, Ewan and Lachlan Maclean covered more than 14,000km from Peru to Cairns, where they became the first team to finish the full crossing just before midday on Saturday. items.title: Robyn Williams’s favourite stories from 50 years of the Science Show
items.standfirst: Fifty years ago today, Australia's longest running science program was born. Robyn Williams picks some of his favourite stories from his time behind the mic.
items.content: Fifty years ago today, Australia's longest running science program was born. Robyn Williams picks some of his favourite stories from his time behind the mic.

ai_summary: Australia's longest-running science program, The Science Show, marks fifty years.
Robyn Williams, the show's host, selected favorite stories from his tenure.
The program began broadcasting fifty years ago today.
Williams has been behind the microphone for the entire duration.
The stories represent a range of scientific topics covered over time.

clusters.title: Public art may do more than simply brighten our streets
clusters.neutral_headline: Public Art's Potential Role in Improving Public Health Explored

items.title: Public art may do more than simply brighten our streets
items.standfirst: As murals pop up in laneways, one researcher asks how public art can play a role in improving public health.
items.content: As murals pop up in laneways, one researcher asks how public art can play a role in improving public health.

ai_summary: Researchers are investigating the impact of public art on public health.
Murals and other public art installations are appearing in laneways.
The study examines the potential benefits of these art projects.
The research aims to understand art's role in community well-being.
The focus is on how art can contribute to improved public health outcomes.

clusters.title: Motorcycle rider killed, child seriously hurt on WA roads
clusters.neutral_headline: Motorcycle Rider Killed, Child Seriously Injured in WA Crashes

items.title: Motorcycle rider killed, child seriously hurt on WA roads
items.standfirst: A motorcycle rider has died and a toddler is in a serious condition after separate crashes within an hour of each other on WA roads yesterday.
items.content: A motorcycle rider has died and a toddler is in a serious condition after separate crashes within an hour of each other on WA roads yesterday.

ai_summary: A motorcycle rider died in a crash on Western Australian roads.
A toddler sustained serious injuries in a separate incident.
The crashes occurred within an hour of each other.
The locations of the crashes were not specified in the report.
Authorities are investigating the circumstances of both incidents.

clusters.title: Domestic violence survivor warns pepper spray would have armed her abuser
clusters.neutral_headline: Domestic Violence Survivor Warns Against Pepper Spray Legalization

items.title: Domestic violence survivor warns pepper spray would have armed her abuser
items.standfirst: The NT government is legalising pepper spray in a bid to improve personal safety, but a domestic violence survivor and experts say the plan will hand violent perpetrators a new weapon.
items.content: The NT government is legalising pepper spray in a bid to improve personal safety, but a domestic violence survivor and experts say the plan will hand violent perpetrators a new weapon.

ai_summary: The Northern Territory government plans to legalize pepper spray.
A domestic violence survivor opposes the proposed legislation.
Experts also express concerns about the plan's implications.
They argue pepper spray could become a weapon for abusers.
The government's aim is to improve personal safety.

clusters.title: House painter turned 'kaleidoscope bus' artist finds his calling
clusters.neutral_headline: House Painter Finds Calling as Kaleidoscope Bus Artist
bullet_summary: It was at the kitchen table, where his children were painting with watercolours, that he found his calling

items.title: House painter turned 'kaleidoscope bus' artist finds his calling
items.standfirst: At 33, house painter Jeff Morgan broke his hand and suffered a strange injury that unravelled his life. It was at the kitchen table, where his children were painting with watercolours, that he found his calling.
items.content: At 33, house painter Jeff Morgan broke his hand and suffered a strange injury that unravelled his life. It was at the kitchen table, where his children were painting with watercolours, that he found his calling.

ai_summary: Jeff Morgan, a house painter, became a "kaleidoscope bus" artist.
At 33, he suffered a hand injury that changed his life.
He found inspiration while watching his children paint.
He now creates art on a bus using vibrant colors.
The article details his transition and artistic journey.

clusters.title: Aussie qualifier Priscilla Hon bows out of US Open
clusters.neutral_headline: Australian Priscilla Hon Eliminated from US Open Tournament

items.title: Aussie qualifier Priscilla Hon bows out of US Open
items.standfirst: The inspired US Open run from qualifying is over for Australian Priscilla Hon following a third-round loss at Flushing Meadows.
items.content: The inspired US Open run from qualifying is over for Australian Priscilla Hon following a third-round loss at Flushing Meadows.

ai_summary: Australian tennis player Priscilla Hon lost in the US Open third round.
Her run in the tournament ended after qualifying.
The report does not specify her opponent or the score.
Hon's performance was considered inspiring by some.
She was defeated at Flushing Meadows.
